Institution Name: William and Mary, The College of

Cost: Work with natural, cultural resource management agencies e.g. National Park Service, US Forest Service for 2 to 5 weeks. Teams of 6 to 8 students work together on conservation assignment.  $25 application fee, $500 program fee.  See website for details.

Description: Jewish Community Center of Northern Virginia (JCCNV)
Cost: JCCNV is looking for dynamic, fun, and motivated counselors to join the J Camp team. Ideal applicants will be able to work all summer long. Full attendance at orientation (always the week prior to the start of camp) is a must.  See website for details.

The Research and Engineering Apprenticeship Program (REAP) provides opportunities for high school students from historically underrepresented and underserved populations. Students gain hands-on work experience in scientific research and development programs on a university level. REAP students are exposed to real world scientific research and are able to see themselves making a living as scientists and researchers. Selected students are awarded a stipend for their summer research experience in a university lab.

One week long training event for high school students at the FBI Academy every summer. Individuals interested in attending the Youth Leadership Program (YLP) are requested to contact their local chapter officers for further information. See website for more details.

Richard Louie Memorial Internship: For students 16+ of Asian descent or who have interest in Asian art/culture. Internship may be paid or unpaid, must work 200 hours to be considered for a $1,500 stipend. Internship is for school year or during summer, applicants must choose one session. Go to website for complete instructions.

Program Name: UPMC Hillman Cancer Center Academy (formerly UPCI Academy)
Description: Pittsburgh, University of Cancer Institute Summer Academy
Cost: Eight weeks of didactic and experiential learning at five different locations: The Magee Women's Cancer Research Center;The Tumor Immunology site; The Drug Discovery - Systems and Computational Biology site; and The Computer Sciences, Biological Sciences and Biomedical Informatics site. See website for details. Some exceptional 10th graders accepted. Out of state students have to pay for on-campus housing fee (about $7,000). Stipend is awarded to eligible students.

Description: Smithsonian Institution - National Museum of Natural History
Cost: A career immersion and science communication program for youth between the ages of 13-19, who are currently enrolled in high school in the Washington D.C. region. The YES! program, which runs from June-October, gives interns practical experience through a hands-on science internship with Smithsonian science staff

8-week full time internship provides students a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to work side by side with expert Smithsonian Libraries and Smithsonian staff to acquire the latest skills, knowledge, and hands-on experience needed for today’s information and cultural heritage marketplace. See website for various opportunities and deadlines.

Description: Youth Programs at National Park Services
Cost: The Youth Conservation Corps is a federally funded work-learn-earn program aimed at developing an appreciation and understanding of the Nation’s environmental and natural heritage.  Students will spend the majority of the summer outside assisting us with visitor services, maintenance, and biological duties. Environmental awareness is an integral aspect of the YCC program, with projects embracing both work and environmental learning goals.  Check the website for locations of opportunities and application windows.

A week-long summer science immersion program at the University of Maryland. The theme for the 2019 program is biomedical science. Students will learn how cellular and molecular techniques are changing the way we diagnose and treat disease. Participants are responsible for transportation to and from campus each day; no on-site housing is available.

BWSI is a rigorous STEM program for rising seniors. It features hands-on, project-based, workshop-style courses beginning with online courses from January to March (online registration begins December 1st).  The 4-week Summer Institute applications are due in Mid-March.  See website for details.
Cost Type: Students will pay transportation costs. Program is free.

Cost: The NYSC is a month-long camp for young scientists conducted during the summer after they graduate from high school.  In a rustic setting in West Virginia, students from around the country are challenged academically in exciting lectures and hands-on studies on current science topics.  The program also offers participants the opportunity to experience a wide variety of outdoor activities that have a minimal impact on the environment and are challenging for the experienced but accessible to those who have never participated in outdoor excursions.  The NYSC is an all-expenses-paid program.  The National Youth Science Foundation will arrange round trip transportation from an airport near the delegate’s home to Charleston, West Virginia.

Program Name: SUMMER INTERNSHIP PROGRAM IN BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH FOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS (HS-SIP)
Cost:
High School SIP provides an opportunity to spend a summer working at the NIH side-by-side with some of the leading scientists in the world, in an environment 
devoted exclusively to biomedical research. For citizens and permanent residents of the U.S. See Website for details.

Program Name: Lott Leadership Institute for High School Students
Cost: Month long program that brings together student leaders from across the Southeast to earn college credit on the UM campus and to begin the study of leadership. The goals of the program are to develop leadership skills in young citizens and prepare them for college.  Focus on politics and public service. Includes trip to Washington DC. Nominations from schools MUST be received by December 15, 2018. See website for details.

Description: Indiana University Kelley School of Business
Cost: Two weeks program to immerse yourself in the cultures and languages of East Asia, the Middle East and North Africa, Russia and Eastern Europe, the Netherlands, Belgium, Suriname, and the Dutch-speaking islands of the Caribbean while exploring career options.

Program Name: Joint Science Education Project (JSEP) &  The Joint Antarctic School Expedition (JASE)
Cost: A project funded by the National Science Foundation that provides opportunities for U.S. high school students and Dartmouth graduate students to travel to the polar regions and participate in hands-on and inquiry-based science activities. The Joint Science Education Project (JSEP) takes students to Greenland and the Joint Antarctic School Expedition (JASE) takes students to Antarctica.
Deadline: JSEP 3 weeks summer 2019               JASE 1-2 weeks winter 2019-20

Cost: International group promoting commitment to service and leadership. Camp offers service projects, outdoor experience, artistic activities.  4 week sessions.  See website for details.

Program Name: BLAST (Building Leaders for Advancing Science & Tech)
Description: Virginia Space Grant Consortium/UVA & Virginia Tech
Cost: BLAST will offer dynamic three-day residential summer experiences on the campuses of Old Dominion University, Virginia Tech and University of Virginia. Through innovative hands-on sessions taught by faculty members and staff, students will explore the fun and excitement of STEM while residing in a college dorm. Current 8th & 9th Virginia Residents only.

Program Name: Tisch School of the Arts - Summer High School Programs
Cost: Four week intensive training in the arts.  Structured class schedule which includes projects, professional training, and collaboration. Tuition-based and culminates in six college college credits . Nonrefundable online application fee of $75 and activity fees additional. Need-based scholarships available.

HSD is a ten-day program at Princeton University for American students to interact and forge friendships with Japanese students. Accepts 40 American participants. Ability to speak Japanese not required. Full scholarships are awarded to student participants. Online application
8 week unpaid volunteer program for students interested in scientific research. Student will work directly with a scientist on cutting edge research.

Program Name: USU Comprehensive Student Research Training Program (USU-CSRTP)
Description: Uniformed Services University of the Health and Science
Cost: The USU-CSRTP is a 9-week training program that provides unique exposure to basic (USRTP) and clinical research, social/behavioral research, health policy, and research administration to high school and college students

This seven week summer research program is open to gifted students in almost any area of academy from natural sciences and mathematics to humanities and fine arts as well. Free room and board. Application includes letter of recommendation and PSAT or SAT scores. Application is very specific for deadlines.

Description: Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History
Cost: Q?rius interns encourage visitor exploration in fun, experimental, and creative activities in the Q?rius exhibit. They serve as ambassadors to engage fellow teens in interactive, science-based activities. Requires a 100-hour commitment in total.
Age Eligibility: 13 to 19 and enrolled in high school

Program Name: High School Introduction to Engineering Systems (HITES)
Cost: One Week long program that provides a hands-on opportunity to explore engineering studies and prepare for scientific study and research at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Must have a minimum ACT math score of 25 or  SAT math score of 590. Program is free, there is $75 processing fee if selected to attend, but students must provide their own transportation cost.
Check website for more info
Check website for more info

Program Name: Internship opportunities with various government agencies
Cost: Many vacancies at various locations for paid positions and internships. Different eligibility requirements and application deadlines for different positions.

Program Name: Diversity in Vision Research & Ophthalmology Internship
Cost: 8-12 week program to conduct and support research to help prevent and treat eye diseases and other vision disorders. Please see NIH web page for application instructions. Stipend equivalent to minimum wage or more, depending on assignment.

a 39-day residential enrichment program designed to challenge and inspire highly gifted high school students in an immersion into hands-on research. The program is held at two locations: Program in Astrophysics  is held at New Mexico Tech and Univ. of Colorado Boulder, Program in Biochemistry takes place at Purdue University

One week residential introduction to applied sciences and awareness on engineering careers for rising 10th grade.  Emphasis on hands on applications and exposure to and preparation for scientific research.  Families cover transportation costs and a parent must attend orientation/closing awards ceremonies.  Application is online. $75 processing fee if chosen to attend.

Program Name: Internships and Other Student Work Opportunities
Cost: Summer programs are from May/June to August. Project areas include earth science, heliophysics, astrophysics, planetary science, engineering, communications and technology development.  Internships are held at various locations. For more information,go to https://intern.nasa.gov link and click on the Summer Application link.

Description: The Center for Excellence in Education
Cost: RSI scholars participate in a week of intensive STEM classes. This is followed by a five week research internship where students conduct individual projects under the tutelage of mentors who are experienced scientists and researchers. During the final week, students prepare written and oral presentations on their research projects. The program is held at MIT. Transportation not included.  $65 application fee. See website for details and deadlines.

Program Name: High School Startup Incubator (formerly Catapult Ideas)
Cost: Quarter Zero, provides a structured, immersive, real-world learning experience for students with a drive and curiosity for solving problems. The program provides participants with an unprecedented, immersive entrepreneurial experience. Students gather for three four-day intensives, each time in an entrepreneurial-focused city. Between sessions, the ventures are refined and iterated on with the guidance of advisors. The incubator culminates in a Demo Day where founders pitch to judges in the hopes of gaining valuable feedback, new mentors, and prospective seed-level investments. Application is opened for Summer 2019 Incubators. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis until the cohorts are full so apply as soon as possible. See website for more details.
Cost Amount: $6,800 Tuition and fees. Scholarships are available

Cost: 8-wk paid internship w/ local non-profit organization (start date determined on indiv basis). Includes week in July (07/08/19-07/13/19) in DC at Student Leadership Summit (free as part of the program). Learn how nonprofits, government & businesses partner in the community. Apply online.

Description: Johns Hopkins Whiting School of Engineering
Cost: Engineering Innovation is a 4 or 5 weeks (depending on the site) summer program  with hands-on lab activities in the fields of chemical, electrical, mechanical, civil engineering, materials science, and robotics.  Completion of  prerequisite courses is required for application, multiple sites in Maryland and DC area.  See website for details.

Program Name: Summer Talent Academy for Professions in Health (STAPH)
Cost: The Summer Talent Academy for Professions in Health (STAPH) offers highly-talented students interested in science and health a head start on college life and future careers in medicine and allied health professions. Students live on campus and work and learn in the healthcare and medical facilities. They address real problems confronted by healthcare professionals.  Nominations due Nov 30. 2018

Unpaid internship for online, nonprofit firm. PR, marketing, communications, fundraising, finance, tech mgmt, translation. Min. duration of 3 weeks, at least 10 hrs/wk. Two internships available: Development or Research. Send application to info@givology.org.  See website for details.

Program Name: The Science and Engineering Apprentice Program (SEAP)
Cost: Apprenticeships in science and engineering at Department of Defense laboratories through summer research and engineering experiences. Program dates, age and grade requirements vary by lab. Check website for deadline date (some sites have an earlier deadline date).
Deadline: Program dates, age and grade requirements vary by lab.
Special Considerations: U.S. citizen or permanent legal residents

Cost: Perform scientific research at George Mason University's Fairfax & Prince William campuses in proteomics, genomics, neuroscience, biochemistry, environmental biology and more. Program runs for 7.5 weeks.

Rigorous four-week summer academic and residential experience for female students to explore engineering and computer science. Program designed for girls who have already demonstrated their ability to excel in math and science, but who have very little or no prior background in engineering or computer science. Scholarships available based on financial need.  See website for details.

Three week residential program working on park conservation and development projects at various parks. Students can choose session but not park. Room and board and camp t shirt provided. At the completion of the program, interns receive $500.

The SSP is a ten-week research internship in mammalian genetics and genomics. Internships are offered at The Jackson Laboratory (Bar Harbor, Maine), and the Jackson Laboratory for Genomic Medicine (Farmington, Connecticut). Students will conduct independent research as part of a lab team seeking to advance our understanding of the causes and treatment of disease. Students may select from a range of projects including bioinformatics, computational biology, genomics, developmental, neurobiology, reproductive biology, metabolism, immunology, aging, cancer, and many more. See website for more details.

Description: Smithsonian Institution - National Science Resources Center
Cost: Part of Smithsonian Institute. List of internship opportunities. Application deadlines vary with the specific internship. See website for deadlines and opportunities.

Program Name: Al Neuharth Free Spirit and Journalism Conference
Cost: For rising Seniors who have a passion for journalism. Recipients will attend a five-day, all-expenses-paid journalism conference at the Newseum in Washington, D.C. and will be awarded college scholarships. See website for application instructions.
Gain an understanding of the challenges and rewards of an Air Force Cadet. 5 day program. Apply online from 12/1/2018 to 1/15/2019. See website for more details.
Special Considerations: Attendees responsible for travel to Air Force Academy

Cost: A four-week program that exposes high school students to the topics of entrepreneurship, globalization, team building, project management, leadership and working within a culturally diverse environment. (Formerly The Pennsylvania School for Global Entrepreneurship)

A four-week program that introduces high school students to the world of health care, including issues of primary care, prevention, public health, career exploration, human growth and development, and areas of practice.

TASS is a challenging, six-week summer seminar on topics related to critical Black and ethnic studies. The seminars will be held at Cornell University and the University of Michigan. Apply online.  Students are responsible for travel costs.  Need-based aid may be available. See website for details.

Two-week summer program with academic tracks to satisfy any student’s thirst for knowledge. Many programs to choose from.  Successful completion can earn one college credit.  See website for details and costs. Limited need based aid may be available; see website for application and deadlines.

Ten-day summer seminar for students interested in American Arts, Popular Culture, and Social Change, Global Issues – Towards a Just Peace, and Science, Ethics and Responsibility. All Expenses Paid except application fee. One college credit.  Online application; see website for details.

Students of Jewish background, age 16 by July 1. Five week summer fellowship program limited to 26 outstanding teenagers involving travel to and study about the land and people of Israel. The fellowship year continues with seminars in Dec.& April in NY. See website for details.

4 week program to give students the training and resources to start a business. To be held at MIT, taught by LaunchX staff, experienced entrepreneurs, business professionals, and university instructors.   Early Admissions Deadline: 12/21/18. Regular Admissions Deadline: 02/25/19.

The program provides high school students with a unique and personalized opportunity to conduct hands-on research under the mentorship of leading scientists at one of the world's premier biomedical research facilities. During this rigorous 7-week program SSRP students become immersed in scientific culture while gaining an appreciation for the process of biomedical discovery. Through a combination of laboratory experimentation, interactive lectures, and dynamic coursework, students will learn fundamental research techniques, become better acquainted with scientific peer-reviewed literature, and improve critical thinking. Program is free but student needs to pay for housing, meals, and transportation. Need-based stipends may be available. See website for details.

Conduct science demonstrations on aviation and space exploration work with the Discovery Station program, assist with special events during the year. Training is provided. They work at least 15 hours each month. High school students start as volunteer Explainers. After completing 100 volunteer hours, high school students may be considered for paid status based on their performance.
Deadline: No specific start or end dates

Cost: Summer Residential Governor’s Schools provide gifted high school juniors and seniors with intensive educational experiences in visual and performing arts; humanities; mathematics, science, and technology; or through mentorships in marine science, medicine and health sciences, or engineering..

TASP is a six-week educational experience for high school juniors focussing on critical inquiry, self-governance, and service.  Telluride students, or TASPers, chose to attend one of six session held at University of Maryland, Cornell University, and University of Michigan where they participate in public-speaking program, attend lectures by guest speakers, and hold other social and intellectual activities as a community. Students may apply directly online.  See website for details.

Please see website for full details. Many exciting opportunities for summer, spring break and throughout the year. Application dates vary. Internships can be at any of the Smithsonian locations around the DC area, and may include the summer camps for young children.

Description: Amigos de las Americas Washington DC Chapter
Cost: Opportunity to live in a new country and work on sustainable community service projects while living with a host family.  Program ranges 2 to 8 weeks.   Early application deadline Nov. 5th, 18; Regular deadline Dec 3rd, 18.
Cost Type: See website for cost and fundraising information

Cost: Looking for an opportunity to develop leadership skills, volunteer and build a resume that will set you apart from the crowd? Intern with Camp Invention! The program will empower you to build leadership and communication skills while impacting the lives of young innovators and creative thinkers in your community!  See website for details, application, and locations.

Free 1 wk introduction to business and the market economy. Highlight of program is a business simulation where teams run their own business competing against other teams. Students are required to provide their own transportation.
Geographic Location:
On the campus of Wabash College in
Crawfordsville, Indiana.

Program Name: The Sorensen Institute High School Leaders Program (HSLP)
Cost: The program offers concentrated study in Virginia politics and government for high school students from across the state.  The program will take place at UVA on July 13-27, 2019.  Please see websites for details.

gives academically talented, motivated high school students the opportunity to engagein hands-on research in science, math or engineering at Stony Brook University. SimonsFellows work with distinguished faculty mentors, learn laboratory techniques and tools,become part of active research teams, and experience life at a research university.

Sophomores and Juniors  interested in careers in law, government or public service, are invited to participate in the School Board’s Student Leadership Development Program.  Students will participate in several School Board events throughout the year, work with School Board members and gain valuable experience in leadership and decision-making.  Students who would like to participate should submit an application and one-page statement of interest to the principal by Oct 15, 2018.

Description: Fall Opportunities at Hidden Oaks Nature Center
Cost: Hidden Oaks Nature Center is looking for someone 16 or older to work at the front desk on Sundays from 12:00-2:30pm or 2:30-5:00pm.  Main duties would be greeting visitors, answering the phone and taking messages.  Ideal commitment would be for 6 month but students can work every other week if they prefer.  Interested students may contact Fiona Davies at fiona.davies@fairfaxcounty.gov or call 703-941-1065

Program Name: The Washington Journalism and Media Conference
Cost: Outstanding current 10th and 11th grade students are nominated (or self-nominated) to be National Youth Correspondents based on a demonstrated interest in journalism & media, & the ability to be exceptional representatives for their states and high schools. Min GPA 3.5, demonstrated interest in journalism. Receives one college credit. Partial need based scholarship deadline December 07, 2018. Check website for details

Program Name: Washington Youth Summit on the Environment
Cost: The Summit is a hands-on, interactive program that provides America’s highest achieving high school students with an interest in the environment, conservation and sustainability, and with the desire to explore careers in the fields of environmental science, conservation, policy, law and engineering, with a remarkable opportunity. Students are nominated (or self-nominated). Min GPA 3.5. Partial need-based scholarships deadline December 07, 2018.  Check website for details.

PRIMES-USA  is a free year-long program open to juniors that offers original mathematics research projects provided by MIT faculty and mentored by MIT graduate students via the Internet, using software and hardware tools for online collaboration. Attend annual PRIMES conference at MIT and submit your project to science competition.

The Fairfax County Youth Leadership Program is designed to educate and motivate high school students to become engaged citizens and leaders in the community. The Program was established to reach the next generation of citizens and to increase and enhance positive public awareness, participation in local government, and exploration of careers in public service. During a one year period, the program includes a series of monthly sessions about County government, work assignments related to each sessions, a three-weeks summer internship in a County agency and a presentation to middle school civics classes.

The Virginia Earth System Science Scholars (VESSS) program is an interactive online science, technology, engineering and mathematics learning experience for Virginia high school juniors and seniors, highlighted by a seven-day residential summer academy at NASA Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia. Students selected to participate in the program are immersed in NASA-related research through interaction with scientists, engineers and technologists.
Deadline: 6/22 – 6/28 or 7/13-7/19 Dec-May (on-line coursework).  Summer internships dates vary
Special Considerations: For Online course, US resident or citizen. For Summer Academy at NASA Langley Research Center, US citizen.

Description: Virginia Aerospace Science and Technology Scholars
Cost: The Virginia Aerospace Science and Technology Scholars (VASTS) program is an interactive on-line science, technology, engineering and mathematics learning experience, highlighted by a seven-day residential summer academy at NASA Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va. Students selected to participate in the program are immersed in NASA-related research through interaction with scientists, engineers and technologists.
The Science and Engineering Apprenticeship Program (SEAP) provides an opportunity for high school students to participate in research at a Department of Navy (DoN) laboratory during the summer.

Description: NSLI for Youth (National Security Language Initiative for Youth)
Cost: US State Department study abroad scholarship program to study less commonly taught languages. Previous language study not required. Part of a U.S. government initiative that prepares American citizens to be leaders in a global world. See website for details.
Deadline: Mid to late June thru early to late August.

Program Name:
Higher Education Research Experiences (HERE)
at ORNL for entering college freshmen 2019
Cost: Apply through the zintellect.com site.  Choose from 6 disciplines of research.  Once application is complete, students can reach out via email to contacts in those areas.  Stipend and housing allowance for students and a limited travel reimbursement for students whose permanent address is more than 50 miles from Oak Ridge.

Cornerstones is a nonprofit organization that promotes self-sufficiency by providing support and advocacy for those in need of food, shelter, affordable housing, quality childcare, and other human services. See website for details about the current volunteer opportunities.

Kashmir World Foundation develops sustainable projects with an emphasis on the importance of education, training, employment to empower communities to protect their environment and endangered species.   See website for details about the current internships opportunities.

Community service-based, adventure travel programs ranging from 15 to 28 days in 17 countries around the world. Programs divided into 3 categories: Global Action, Language Immersion and Enrichment. See website for details.

Description: Inova Fairfax Hospital, Inova Loudoun Hospital, and Inova Alexandria Hospital
Cost: HELP volunteers offer assistance and activities that keep elderly patients mentally and physically active, which greatly helps their recovery.   Volunteers need to be at least 15 years old and must commit to at least one 3-hour shift per week.  Visit the website for more info.
Deadline: Flexible dates year round (3 hours per week minimum).

Description: Fairfax Co Democratic Committee Summer Intern
Cost: The interns help get organized by contacting voters, improving contact data, helping with mailers, making campaign buttons, working at events like rallies, parades, fairs, and festivals. The interns meet elected officials, go on field trips to the US Capitol and pick up good job experience that can pay off when they get out of school.

Students receive policy briefings and resolve issues in a model Student Congress. Program takes place on the Oklahoma Christian University Campus and is built around the core principles of character, common vision, communication and caring. Costs covered by sponsors and scholarships.

Paid research internship at the Rockville Maryland location or the La Jolla, CA location. Summer 2018 internship positions will be posted in the February/March timeframe. All positions are posted on a rolling basis.  See website for details.

Two to four day free programs for female students. Various sessions and locations in US. Applicants are responsible for lodging and transportations to the camp if live outside of the camp area.  See website for details.
Various counselor positions for seniors at TIC summer camp. See website for details. Do not apply unless you are available the whole summer.

Volunteer archaeology and historic preservation program at National Forests and Federal public lands throughout the U.S. Program is free, but participants must pay for travel, lodging, meals, etc. Some programs available for students under 18. See "Kids Friendly Project" listing on the web page.
Cost Amount: Program is no cost but travel, lodging, meals, etc are not provided

Cost: 12 teens plan and host events that bring DC area teens to the Freer and Sackler Museums. Students must be available during school year and summer.  See website for info and to apply for the 2019-2020 Teen Council.
Cost Type: Paid $600 program award or community service hours

Cost: This is a virtual program that allows participation through televideo conferencing from home or school. Students interested in brain imagery and computer sciences are encouraged to apply. Research in the following fields may be considered: mathematics, statistics, computational science and engineering, biomedical signal and image processing, imaging informatics, biomedical informatics, clinical research informatics, digital graphic arts, software user interface engineering, human machine interface engineering, haptics for virtual reality, robotics for prosthetics, biomimicry for biomimetics, web-enabled database engineering, distributed systems and/or mobile computing Selected applicants, who demonstrate financial need, may receive $1000 educational stipends as funded students for their participation in BHAVI 2018. Non-funded students will pay tuition fees of $4000 for BHAVI 2018 if accepted into the full-time summer quarter.  See website for details and application requirements.

Program Name: All Math Summer Camp for H.S. Girls
Cost: Students must have completed high school geometry.  Week long program includes interesting mathematics session each morning and afternoon, problem sessions following each class and evening activities.  Registration fees vary. Scholarship available for need.  See website for application and details.
Interns work on projects such as exploring ways to improving air traffic control system or improving affordability and accessibility of healthcare.  See website for detail.

A week-long, hands-on academic day camp designed to introduce high school students to the exciting and important field of materials science and engineering, held in Drexel University, Philadelphia. Students responsible for their own housing and transportation.

Program Name: Vernon L. Smith High School Workshop in Experimental Economics
Cost: One-week long workshop on experimental economics. The goal is to cultivate interest in economics and introduce students to economics as an observational science with new topics, problems, and experiments. This workshop does not assume any previous study in economics. The program is free of cost, but participants must pay for transport to Chapman University and room and board while they are there.
Students are able to work for 1-2 weeks on peer reviewed scientific field research with team of research professionals. Worldwide locations.

5 week residential program designed for high school students of color who have a strong interest in the areas of engineering, math, science and business. See website for details.  This program provides students with real college experience. Students enroll in college-level courses to develop functional, quantitative and qualitative skills.

The YLI is a four-day, overnight, college empowerment conference for 150 Latino high school juniors.  It is designed to give these young leaders the practical tools they need to successfully apply to top universities, have full access to scholarship and financial aid opportunities, and set a course for academic and career success.  Attendees will enhance their leadership abilities and expand their professional networks by participating in college and career workshops, living on a college campus, and interacting with college students and professionals who serve as their mentors.  The conferences are hosted each summer at various college campuses across the country.
Deadline:
June 20 - June 23, 2019 - University of Chicago

July 25 - 28, 2019 - University Southern California (USC)

Cost: Every year the Smithsonian highlights one or more cultures in this early-summer festival on the Mall in downtown Washington. Summer interns are expected to work through the ten days of the Festival during the last week of June and first week of July, including weekends and the July Fourth holiday. You should be comfortable working outdoors in high heat and humidity, in a fast-paced environment among large crowds of people

For rising 9th, 10th, 11th and 12th grade girls. Learn physics including relativity, quantum computing and hands on lab activities in topics that expand beyond high school physics classes. Program is nonresidential.

Description: Indiana University Kelley School of Business
Cost: MEET Kelley is a pre-college summer program for high-ability students from underrepresented groups to get introduced to the Kelley School of Business, learn the opportunities available, experience a professional business case competition. Participants cover transportation costs.  Only women. 4 Sessions: June 2019

Program matches high-potential and gifted high school students with distinguished mentors, hands-on research opportunities, and professional experience in their field of interest. Externs advance their skills through the pursuit of knowledge, involvement in research, and exposure to learning experiences. See website for further details.

Annual Global Youth Summit on the Future of Medicine is for interested young people who want to gain experience in medicine and healthcare. Opportunities to experience cutting-edge research at clinical facilities in the greater Boston area. Deposit $280 due 5/1/2018, balance due 5/15/2018.  Limited number of need-based scholarships available.

Description: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Cost: 5 day academic day camp in which campers take on the role of disease detectives and learn how the CDC safeguards the nation's health. Held at CDC's headquarters in Atlanta. No boarding provided.
9 day camp for Latino students interested in legal careers. $50 registration fee.

At the Hampshire College. Study some of the most influential and essential works of modern Jewish literature with highly respected literary scholars. Meet prominent contemporary authors, and connect with other teens from across the country who love to read and want to explore Jewish culture.
This is a highly selective one week program that allows high school business students to be exposed to real world executives and learn what it takes to become a leader.  See website for details.
Cost Type: Tuition and Board are free. $300 for food

Cost: Students of African American descent or students who have an interest in African American culture encouraged to apply. Introduces the strengths of a liberal arts education through an array of courses in science, art, social sciences, and technology. Transportation, tuition, room and board, & travel costs (not including baggage fees) are free for accepted students.

Free six day business programs. Transportation not included. Offered are Discover Yourself in Accounting Majors and Careers (DYNAMIC) and McCombs Future Executive Academy (MFEA). Lower Income, Minority, and Texas residents given priority.

Six day-long introduction to the Coast Guard Academy. Experience the rigor, discipline, and rewards of the Academy, just like a cadet. Success at AIM is a good indicator of success at the Coast Guard Academy. Some scholarships available. Participants are responsible for their own transportation to and from the Academy, as well as a minimal tuition fee.

Explore biological sciences, particularly cancer research, with hands-on laboratory research opportunities. Attend and present findings at work-in-progress sessions with postdoctoral fellows and graduate students. Must participate for the entire program of eight weeks. Apply online.

The Teen Docents will lead gallery tours and educational experiences for the public in the Smithsonian Libraries exhibits.  This free program gives students the opportunity to learn about library and museum careers and get a behind-the-scenes view of the Smithsonian as well as earning service hours.  Mandatory training days in June. At least 2 hours/week and 30 hours overall.  See website for details
A seven-week, intensive summer research program designed for motivated students from across the United States who wish to gain more experience conducting research.  See website for details.

Program Name: Summer Academy for Mathematics and Science (SAMS)
Cost: Rigorous residential program for students considering careers in engineering, science and other math-based disciplines, who are from underrepresented communities, are from families where they will be the first to go to college in the U.S., or are otherwise overcoming challenges to college access. Free tuition, room & board. Students are responsible for books and other course expenses, which average $300. This is part of Carnegie Mellon's Summer Programs for Diversity.
Cost Type: Free, materials fee varies by program

Cost: These are residential camps. Throughout the week, students will explore the different engineering majors while participating in hands-on activities. Sessions will be led by engineering faculty members, Auburn engineering students and engineering organizations. Separate camps for juniors (rising 10th and 11th) and seniors. Costs differ for camps.  See website for details.

SAME Camps are designed for high school students who excel in STEM and are interested in pursuing a degree in STEM in college  Selection to the Camps is competitive. Please visit website for application deadlines and other details.

SAME Camps are designed for high school students who excel in STEM and are interested in pursuing a degree in STEM in college  Selection to the Camps is competitive. Please visit website for application deadlines and other details.

Program Name: Research Mentorship Program, UCSB (2019 applications will open on 12/15/18)
Cost: Participate in academic research in social, life or physical sciences. Some scholarships available. College credit available on select courses. $95 non-refundable application fee.  Apply online.

TJ’s Partnership Fund works with alumni, parents, corporations and friends of TJ to make sure TJ has the equipment and other support it needs to provide an excellent STEM education. The Partnership is looking for 2 student interns to work for during the summer, approximately 6-8 hours per week. Stipend of $750. Come to the CCC for a detailed description of the position and info on how to apply.

Program Name:
Summer Residential Governor’s School for Life Sciences and Medicine

June 30 - July 27, 2019
Cost: GSMHS is a four-week summer program where participants explore medicine and health science careers through a systems-based, problem-solving approach that utilizes case studies, laboratory investigations and real-world shadowing experiences. Participants see the connections among the patient, the community and the health professional. Commitment to full attendance, including an orientation session and closing event, is required to participate.
Cost Type: Housing, primary meals and any other materials required to participate in the program will be provided.
Cost Amount: Transportation and parking are not provided by the program.

Description: Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory, ASPIRE
Cost: The ASPIRE program is the opportunity for juniors and seniors in high school to get hands-on experience in STEM and to explore career opportunities before committing to an area of study in college. The ASPIRE program is a learning experience that exposes students to the real-world applications of what they are learning in school as well as to what it is like to work in a professional environment.
A paid summer mentoring program to educate and inspire high school students about fisheries sciences and management

Program Name: Library of Congress Work Study Program
Cost: The Library accepts applicants from high schools (within a 45 mile radius) and Community College students per program guidelines. Contact school program coordinator for further information on application process.
Age Eligibility: 18; if <18  must have the signed consent of a guardian or other legally authorized individual in the applicable documents.

Cost: Mission: Volunteers and interns serve with diligence, pride, and dedication, and they continue to introduce new ideas, a fresh outlook, and an invigorating spirit to our workforce. Their contributions are highly valued and greatly appreciated by the Police Department and the community it serves.  Currently, our active, highly diverse volunteer corps numbers approximately 200. Volunteers are involved in nearly all aspects of the department’s operations from training to communications. They work side by side in support of the line officers, command staff, and civilian employees.

Program Name: Secret Service Student Volunteer Service Program
Cost: to provide students with an understanding of the nature and the structure of the U.S. Secret Service. The program provides unpaid, academic-related work assignments that allow students to explore career options while developing personal and professional skills. Participants must be currently enrolled in school and are expected to volunteer a minimum of 12 hours per week for at least one semester, two quarters or summer session.
Deadline: minimum of 12 hours per week for at least one semester, two quarters or summer session

Cost: Internships and volunteer opportunities are available across the library.  Areas of work include: acquisitions, cataloging/metadata creation, electronic resource licensing, thesaurus development, and web content strategy.  You may also discover internships and volunteer positions that tie into specific subjects related to agriculture, including: alternative farming systems, animal welfare, food and nutrition, and food safety.

The NIH Summer Internship Program provides opportunities for students to spend the summer working with some of the world's leading scientists in an environment devoted to biomedical research. Students from across the country come to the NIH to obtain scientific research experience and mentoring from scientists and physicians across the 27 Institutes and Centers who study a broad range of questions in biology and medicine.
Deadline: Start dates vary - from mid-May to the end of June and run for at least  8 weeks

Description: National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute
Cost: The goal of the Summer Internship Program in Biomedical Research at NHLBI is to expose students to research investigation in a highly enriched environment that is devoted exclusively to biomedical research and training.  Participants join a research laboratory and conduct research in selected areas of investigation under the guidance of an NHLBI intramural research scientist.
Deadline: Start dates vary - must commit to 10 weeks from June thru August
Special Considerations: Minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale

Program Name: Secret Service Student Volunteer Service Program
Cost: to provide students with an understanding of the nature and the structure of the U.S. Secret Service. The program provides unpaid, academic-related work assignments that allow students to explore career options while developing personal and professional skills. Participants must be currently enrolled in school and are expected to volunteer a minimum of 12 hours per week for at least one semester, two quarters or summer session.
Deadline: minimum of 12 hours per week for at least one semester, two quarters or summer session
Special Considerations:
US Citizen,
NOT be a child of Secret Service agent,

Cost: The Department of Education (ED) offers internships for students interested in seeking valuable work experience in government and federal education policy and administration. Volunteers have the opportunity to make meaningful contributions to the Department's mission to promote student achievement and preparation for global competitiveness by fostering educational excellence and ensuring equal access.
Deadline: 8-10 weeks (flex) in Summer, May/June through July/August

Cost: Interns generally work in one of USAID’s offices in Washington, D.C., supporting programs in fields such as economic growth, agriculture, education, health, environment, democracy and governance, conflict prevention, and humanitarian assistance.

work on a variety of projects tailored to meet your capacity, availability and interests. you'll be encouraged to attend marine conservation events, lectures, conferences and receptions that provide fantastic networking opportunities for your career development.

Program Name: STAR - Summer Trainee in Aging Research Program
Cost: NIA summer internships last from eight to ten weeks, beginning in late May and ending in mid-to-late August. Students receive hands-on experience and attend weekly seminars presented by NIA scientists. At the conclusion of the summer program, students present their data developed from their research project at the NIA Summer Student Poster Day. Program participants receive a stipend which is based on the amount of education completed at the time the fellowship begins.
Special Considerations: reside within 40 miles of the NIH campus

Description: NIH - National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke
Cost: opportunity for academically talented high school, undergraduate, graduate, and medical students to receive first-rate training in neuroscience research. Students get hands-on experience working with leading scientists in the Institute's Division of Intramural Research, the "in-house" research component of the NINDS. NINDS Labs are located in Bethesda, Rockville and Cape Cod, Massachusetts.
Grade, Year in School, Eligibility: high school juniors or seniors at the time of application
Geographic Location: Bethesda, Rockville and Cape Cod, Massachusetts
Special Considerations:
are U.S. citizens or permanent residents, 
live, at the time of application, within 40 miles of the NIH campus on which they will intern

Program Name: SUMMER INTERNSHIP PROGRAM IN BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH FOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS (HS-SIP)
Cost:
High School SIP provides an opportunity to spend a summer working at the NIH side-by-side with some of the leading scientists in the world, in an environment devoted exclusively to biomedical research. The NIH consists of the 240-bed Mark O. Hatfield Clinical Research Center and more than 1150 laboratories/research projects located on the main campus in Bethesda, MD, and the surrounding area as well as in Baltimore and more.

 The NIH Institutes and Centers and the Office of Intramural Training & Education (OITE) sponsor a required summer orientation on each of the start dates that must be completed before the interns join their research groups. The OITE also offers a wide range of summer high school activities including lectures featuring distinguished NIH investigators, career/professional development workshops, college readiness activities, and Summer Poster Day.
Deadline: minimum of eight weeks, must begin on either June 13th and June 24th
Grade, Year in School, Eligibility: high school juniors or seniors at the time of application
Geographic Location: Bethesda, MD, and the surrounding area as well as in Baltimore and more.
Special Considerations:
are U.S. citizens or permanent residents, 
live, at the time of application

Cost: A summer program that provides an opportunity for students to work with scientists in an environment devoted to biomedical research. Research projects include fundamental analyses of protein structure and function, cell biology, signal transduction, gene regulation, tissue development and differentiation, and genetics and immunology. Additionally, research on the genetics, etiology, pathogenesis and treatment of a variety of rheumatic, autoimmune, inflammatory, joint, skin, and muscle diseases is also possible.
Deadline: minimum of eight weeks, beginning in May or June
Special Considerations:
are U.S. citizens or permanent residents, 
live, at the time of application

Program Name: Future Agents in Training (FAIT)                                 (2019 information not available 11/26)
Cost: Program at FBI's Washington Field Office. Hands on training using Special Agent investigative tactics to gather evidence, interview witnesses, capture criminals, and solve cases. All applications and questions must be via email, no phone calls accepted. Applications must be either attached in an email & sent to staff at wfocop@ic.fbi.gov or faxed to 202-278-2675.

Program Name: American University Radio Summer of Service (no information available 11/26/18)
Cost: Fun summer volunteering at WAMU 88.5 four days a week, 20 hours per week. Openings for 2017: Digital Media Producer-Conduct interviews with listeners of WAMU,Assist with the production of multimedia (text, photographs, audio, and graphics) web-only stories for the Listeners of WAMU project, Help manage the WAMU Interns social media accounts (Twitter, SoundCloud, Tumblr, & WordPress).

Program Name:
Young Ambassadors Program                          
(2019 information not available as of 11/29)
Cost: A 3-week Spanish language and culture tour in Costa Rica for a small number of high school students this summer. Dates are July 9-30. Applicants must be US citizens and have been enrolled in Spanish language class

Program Name:
Summer Internship             

(2019 information not available as of 11/29)
Cost: Interns will work 35-40 hours per week on a variety of cutting edge projects including: programming with Python, Java, Javascript, and others; designing virtual reality, mobile, and social media applications, analyzing and managing Big Data using SAS, Hadoop, Spark, MapReduce, ZoomData, and other packages. See website for details.

Program Name:
Summer STEM Scholars Program  


(2019 information not available as of 11/29)
Cost: The new pilot project will support students’ passion for science and allow them to attend a leading university-based STEM research program this summer, receive support for their research, and give them access to extraordinary STEM mentors and technical experts. Interested students, please see Mrs. Kropf of Ms. Andrea Smith for the application. For more information on the foundation, go to: www.ronbrown.org. For specific questions on this new program, contact Ms. Kiya Jones at kjones@ronbrown.org.

Program Name: US Marine Summer Leadership & Character Development Academy
Cost: Free one week course providing leadership training, character development, ethics lessons, and college admissions guidance. Also included are daily physical fitness classes, distinguished speakers, a community service project and a DC field trip. Refer to website for details.

Program Name: WRAIR Gains in the Education of Mathematics and Science
Description: GEMS - Gains in the Education of Mathematics and Science
Cost: One week internships in June, July and August at Walter Reed Army Institute of Research , Fort Detrick, Aberdeen Proving Grounds in Maryland and other US locations. Providing hands on experiences in army laboratories promoting Science, Technology, Engineering and Math. Deadlines, Dates vary by grade level and location. See website for details.

Week-long, hands-on opportunity for Latino/a and African American rising seniors who have a GPA of 3.0 or higher to learn about the accounting profession and accountants' role in society. Residential program-no cost other than transportation.

Program Name: Teen Mentors Program (2018 information not available as of 2/26)
Cost: ArtAbility brings drama, movement, music and visual arts experiences to middle school students on the autism spectrum.  Teen Mentors are being recruited to volunteer and work with the students and families throughout the spring and summer programs for 2016.  Students must be current 10th – 12th graders and will receive community service hours for their involvement in this program.  (Information on 2018 program was not available as of 02/26/18, check website for updates or email info@glenechopark.org with name, phone number and interests.)
Geographic Location: MD Out of DC Metro Area

Cost: One-week residential program for rising junior or senior women who are considering engineering as a possible major and career. Explore the world of engineering through hands-on activities, laboratory experiments, informative workshops, team challenges, and seminars with professional engineers.

Program Name: SMaRT Camp: Summer Mathematics Research Training
Cost: The camp will provide an intensive learning environment in mathematics, where high school students will learn not only useful mathematical facts, but also how to approach mathematical problems, prove mathematical statements, and write the results.
The QuestBridge College Prep Scholars Program prepares outstanding low-income high school juniors to gain admission and full scholarships to top-tier colleges through QuestBridge.

The Summer Immersion Program is a FREE 7-week summer program for 10th-11th grade girls to learn computer science, get exposure to tech jobs and join a supportive sisterhood of thousands of girls across the US.  It's an introductory computer science course and no previous experience is required. See website to apply.

Summer science enrichment through the Center of Excellence at Howard University's School of Pharmacy for students who demonstrate an interest in the sciences, a career in pharmacy or other health professions. Priority given to minority and/or financially disadvantaged candidates.

Program designed to familiarize students with various engineering disciplines offered at UM and to acquaint them with the university campus, support services, and other resources. Team-focussed projects and opportunities to meet with faculty, staff, and students in an informal setting. Get exposed to college life, attend classes and tour the campus.  Along with application, teacher recommendations and SAT/ACT test scores required. See website for additional information.

This program provides intensive training in state & local government, politics, leadership and public service to students from VA. Scholarship and financial aid available. Upon successful completion, earn 3 UVA credits.

Program Name: The Whiteboard Incubator (Application not available for 2019)
Cost: The Whiteboard Incubator is a no-tuition, non equity business program designed for high school students who are either already running their own businesses or have a business concept they want to pursue. Accepted students will receive mentorship and coaching, office space in Cambridge, MA on MIT's campus, and the opportunity to start their own company. To learn more and to apply, visit the website.

A six to eight week research internship in Division of Laboratory Medicine at Children's National Medical Center. Interest in medicine, cancer research or biological sciences. Participate in clinical research. Req: 2 yrs high school chemistry. Start and end dates of the program will be determined based on the selected student's school schedule.

Program Name: Dr Bessie F. Lawrence International Summer Science Institute (2019 info not available Nov 26)
Description: Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel
Cost: Participate in ongoing science research projects at the Weizmann Institute in Rehoboth, Israel. All U.S students attending receive a full $6000 scholarship covering airfare and all costs at the Institute. Link to application: https://www.weizmann-usa.org/media/3548/2018-issi-application.pdf

Program Name: NCAS CAREERS Weather Camps  (2019 info not available Dec 6)
Cost: 2-week residential camp in Howard University covering weather, meteorology, atmospheric sciences, environmental sciences, and applied physical sciences through hands-on activities.  Please see website for details.

Program Name: Project Seed - Internship (2019 information not available 11/26
Cost: Paid 8 - 10 week internship for economically disadvantaged high school students.  Participants are given a rare chance to work alongside scientist-mentors on research projects in industrial, academic, and federal laboratories. Interested students must contact the ACS Project SEED office for a SEED Sponsor in your area between February and May 2018.  Please call 1-800-227-5558 ex. 4380 or email projectseed@acs.org. Please see website for details

Program Name: Summer Engineering Seminar (SES) (2019 information not available 11/26)
Cost: This program is for current high school sophomores and juniors who are interested in exploring the field of engineering. The program is designed to acquaint participants with the engineering profession, the academic expectations of college, and the nature of life at a university. . Live in dorm, attend engineering classes. Tuition, Room/Board all paid by grants. Student to provide own transportation to program.

Program Name: Princeton University Summer Journalism Program (application available early Dec)
Cost: A 10-day seminar  (August 3 to August 13) that is designed to  encourage outstanding high school students from low-income backgrounds to pursue careers in journalism.

JCamp is a six-day intensive journalism training for high school students. Students learn from professional journalists and get hands-on training in writing, photography, television broadcasting, online media, and reporting.2018 JCamp will be held at Wayne State in Detroit, MI. Program not limited to Asian-American students. There is no fee to apply and all costs are covered - including airfare, lodging, and meals.  Learn more and apply for camp at http://www.aaja.org/jcamp2018

Program Name: National Space Club Scholars Program (2019 info not available Nov 26)
Cost: 6 week (non-residential) internship working with a technical professional in earth and space systems science, computer science, or engineering. Must be a US citizen, have permanent residence within commuting distance.  See website for details. Application available at https://intern.nasa.gov
Geographic Location: MD Out of DC Metro Area

Program Name: Discovery to Cure High School Internship (application will be available in Jan, 19)
Cost: The internship is a 6-week, full-time, hands-on research experience in one of Yale's biomedical labs, working under a Principal Investigator. The internship is unpaid, and interns will need to find their own housing in New Haven. TJ may nominate 5 students who will be asked to submit applications. To be nominated for this program, please give hard copies of the following to Mrs. Kropf in the CCC by Monday, Feb. 12, at 4 pm: 1)unofficial transcript 2) resume 3) written answers to the following questions (one paragraph each): What are your primary academic interest areas? Please describe your possible career interests. How certain do you feel you know what you want to do as a career? 4) Essay of no more than 400 words on the following: "How do you think the Discovery to Cure Internship will help you achieve your future goals?" Applications will be reviewed by TJ science faculty and 5 students will be chosen to submit applications. For questions, see Mrs. Kropf.

Program Name: Wolf Trap National Park (opportunites to be posted Dec 28)
Description: Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts
Cost: Work on grounds or in theater. Paid and volunteer opportunities. Most jobs are May-September. Get all the information about summer jobs by attending a Job Fair. Job Fairs for Summer 2018: Thursday, December 28, 4:00-8:00 p.m., Saturday, January 6, 12:00-4:00 p.m., Wednesday, January 10, 4:00-8:00 p.m. See website for more details.
Age Eligibility: 18 for most positions. 13 and up for a few positions

Program Name: Girls on Ice North Cascades (application available in Dec)
Cost: Each year 8-9 teenage girls  are selected to join 3 instructors to form expedition teams to spend 12 days exploring and learning about glaciers and the alpine or marine environment through scientific field studies with professional glaciologists, ecologists, artists, and mountaineer.

Program Name: NSA Gifted and Talented STEM Program for High School  (application date unclear, Dec 6)
Cost: Students work full time for 10 to 12 weeks during the summer following their senior year of high school. The program is designed for students who have demonstrated an aptitude for engineering, math and science.
Geographic Location: MD Out of DC Metro Area

Cost: American Pool is looking for lifeguards.  Interested students can either call 703-579-0885 or go to website for more details.

Program Name: George Washington Carver Summer Research Internship Program(info not available as of 11/19)
Cost: 6 week program (from June 9th to August 4th 2018) promotes “science with practice” by exposing interns to research opportunities under the direction of College of Agriculture and Life Sciences (CALS) research faculty members. See website for details.

Program Name:
Multiple Programs:
- Music
- Summer Scholars
- Mock Trial (Applications will open in January)

Cost: The Summer Scholars program for rising high school juniors and seniors offers opportunities to study under the direction of Furman faculty members. Summer Scholars' challenging academic experience will include lectures, class discussion, debates, laboratory research, field trips, group and individual projects, and other activities.

Program Name:
Wildlife Ecology Day Program 

2018: July 30-August 10 (M-F only), 9am-4pm
Description: Huyck Preserve and Biological Research Station
Cost: intensive 2-week day program where rising juniors and seniors will learn basic ecological principles through hands-on research experience. Ecologists from colleges and universities around the region will instruct students on broad topics in ecology.  Wildlife Ecology Research culminates in small group research projects beginning with a question and ending with a final presentation. This program aims to provide a significant academic experience that will help students prepare for courses and research experiences at the college level while letting them explore career options in the natural sciences.
Cost Amount: Tuition is $475 for Preserve Members and $550 for Non-members

Program Name: AgDiscovery (2019 info will be available in Jan 19)
Description:
United States Department of Agriculture
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
Cost: AgDiscovery is a summer camp outreach program designed to help middle through high school aged students explore careers in animal science, veterinary medicine, agribusiness, plant pathology, aquaculture, and much more. This 2-4 week program allows participants to live on a college campus, and discover agricultural science from university professors, practicing veterinarians, industry representatives, and professionals working for the U.S. government. Students who participate in AgDiscovery experience hands-on labs, workshops, field trips, and other group and team building activities. There are about 22 universities participating in the AgDiscovery program. See Website for details.
Geographic Location: MD Out of DC Metro Area

Program Name: Summer Radio and TV Camp (2019 info not available until January)
Cost: The camps offers students interested in Television and Radio production a great outlet to learn, experience, and create. Each summer we offer 1 week Radio and 2 week Television Camps, which certifies participants in the use of our production equipment and as FPA station producers. Once properly trained, participants can begin volunteering and earn production experience throughout the year by helping in the various public access programs created at FPA or even create a show of their own. The cost is $500 for the TV and $350 for the radio sessions. For more info and to register, please visit the website.

Program Name: Summer Camp Counselor (2019 information not available January)
Cost: The Columbus Club is looking for CITs, Junior Counselors, Lead Counselors, Specialty Counselors (Art, Music, Sports, Swim) and coaches. If you are 14 or 15 you can apply to be a Counselor In Training (volunteers). If you are 16 or 17 you can apply to be a Junior Counselor. If you are 18 or older AND have graduated from high school, you can apply to be a Lead Counselor, Specialty Counselor, or Coach.

Program Name: Summer Program in Algorithmic and Combinatorial Thinking (2019 info not available January)
Cost: 6 - 8 week intensive course in programming and application development with a theoretical and proof-based emphasis. Program is on campus at Princeton University.  Non-residential. Program fee $1250. No accommodation provided.

Program Name: 4-H Camp Counselor Program (2019 info not available January)
Cost: Must be min of 14 to be a counselor. Requirement to participate in pre-camp training. Camp dates Jul 22-26. Here is the link for details and application: https://arlington.ext.vt.edu/programs/4h-camp.html

Program Name: SciTech Summer Research Program in Haifa, Israel
Cost: SciTech is a 3-4 week program which combines scientific research along with cultural and social activities in Haifa, Israel. Participants work either individually or in small groups on a research project of their choice which is supervised by members of the Technion's research staff

Two week residential program in engineering and technology. Limited to 40 participants. Includes tuition, fees,  transportation, room and board. Must pay health care fee. The program is limited to U.S. citizens and permanent residents from underrepresented and underserved backgrounds.

Two to four day free programs for female students. Various sessions and locations in US. Applicants are responsible for lodging and transportations to the camp if live outside of the camp area.  See website for details.

The program provides clear and practical information on college application and available financial aid, and about career and educational opportunities, with focus on Hispanic students. Held at VA Tech. See website for more details.

Three-week service-learning programs in Baltimore (Johns Hopkins University), Chicago (Northwestern University), or UC Berkeley.  Need-based financial aid available. See website for prerequisites. Early bird application deadline 5/14/2019.

Program Name: 10th Congressional District Young Women Leadership Program
Cost: The program provides young women currently enrolled in middle school and high school with the opportunity to meet and interact with women who hold leadership roles in government, business, medicine, media relations, and other professions. Residents of the 10th Congressional District are given priority. (Includes parts of Prince William and Loudoun Counties. See website for boundaries of 10th District.) Participants will have the opportunity to engage with their peers and special guests in candid, roundtable discussions while sharing insights, advice, and stories. They will also learn about career opportunities in various fields, the legislative process, develop their leadership skills, identify their strengths, and practice effective communication with others to inspire their educational and career goals. Program activities and events are in DC and in 10th Congressional District.
Deadline: June 2018 and will continue through the end of August 2018.
Geographic Location: VA -- residents of the 10th Congressional District will be given priority.

Cost: Bose Public Affairs Group is seeking an intern during the summer of 2018 for the firm’s downtown Washington, D.C. offices.  The candidate will provide assistance to the firm’s government relations and communications teams on a wide variety of matters and will gain exposure and experience in all aspects of the legislative and public affairs process
Counselor-in-training program for Park Authority Rec-Pac Summer Camps. See website for details.
